If you’ve ever dreamed of creating your own zoo while suffering through a four-hour slog of decision paralysis, Ark Nova is your dream and your nightmare come true. Don’t let the lush box art fool you—this is less about building a zoo and more about turning your game night into an existential crisis.

Let’s start with the theme: You’re running a zoo, but not just any zoo. No, this is a hyper-complex bureaucracy simulator disguised as a board game. Want to bring in a lion? Great! But first, navigate the world’s most convoluted action-selection system, wrestle with an unintuitive card market, and somehow not fall asleep while your friend takes 20 minutes to figure out whether they want to donate to conservation or build a kiosk. (Spoiler: It’s always the kiosk.)

Speaking of conservation, Ark Nova is obsessed with reminding you that zoos aren’t just about cute animals—they’re also about saving the planet. That would be fine if it didn’t feel like a tacked-on guilt trip every time you try to build an enclosure for penguins instead of adopting some obscure tree frog. And let’s not forget the “exciting” gameplay loop of desperately hoping the one card you need isn’t buried at the bottom of the draw pile. Thrilling.

Oh, and the player board? A chaotic mess. It’s a patchwork quilt of icons, tracks, and tokens that looks like it was designed by someone who hates clarity. You’ll spend half the game squinting at your board, wondering where your worker went and why you even decided to play this monstrosity in the first place.

But the real kicker? The game’s length. By hour three, you’ll be begging for a meteor to hit your zoo just so you can finally stop playing. Meanwhile, the “winning” player will smugly explain how they scored 50 points off a lemur card you didn't even know existed.

So, if you love games that take forever, make you question your friendships, and leave you more stressed than entertained, Ark Nova is the game for you. Everyone else? Stick to Ticket to Ride and call it a day.

I have rated 924 items with an average rating of about 8, with only 7 items receiving a 1. This is one of them.

The game is a pure luck of the draw card game that tries very, very, very hard to disguise that fact. I am genuinely, deeply, and utterly baffled why it is rated so highly.

You may end up completely unable to do anything of significance, or can get good combos, only to lose to a player that simply drew into better ones. Players that draw cards that are strong early or late, at the proper time, get ahead while others just languish. The hand size is laughably small, making it nearly impossible to set up a big combo play for a subsequent round. There is no realistic opportunity to pivot your strategy on a round by round basis, or to take a gamble on a strategy with a plan B, or to set up something for later with options to go in another direction. There's no common mechanism for doing something with cards in your hand that you no longer want to build, to spend towards something else. How did somebody make this game in a world after the creation of Terraforming Mars, with a straight face? Or Race for the Galaxy, for that matter? I don't even particularly love those games.

Also, it has the very WORST money tokens I have ever seen in a game. The cherry on top is the horrifically designed board/play area/component layout that takes up way more room than it has any right to. Good luck fiddling with the cards on the board without knocking over the terrible, skinny pawns that keep track of everything.

BUT, I think this game is broken. I've played two interminable playthroughs of this game, because I wanted to give it a second shot after the first. The first playthrough was interestingly instructive as well. I'll cut to the chase and home in to what the problem with the game is.

The game has a massive deck of cards. It's so tall when laid out that you cannot see anything around it, when sitting at a table. It obscures the scores that players are at (very closely to where they tend to be for the end game to trigger, by the way), and for some of us it even obscured this first visible draftable card. Shuffling this deck requires you to book a holiday. You cannot physically shuffle it in one go unless you're Shaquille O'Neal. If you have human hands, you will have to shuffle it in multiple stretches, one bit at a time.

For our first playthrough I didn't shuffle it very well, so we ended up having lots of synergetic cards close to one another, which generated these action chains when played. This is fundamentally where the engine building fun is supposed to live in this game. I was able to get these long chains of synergetic events every time I would play a new animal in my stack because of the bad shuffling. This made these events dull for all other players. It become dull for me! This fox activates my other fox, which allows me to get a card, then thanks to this sponsor I get 3 points. This other animal allows me to immediately play another animal, etc etc...

So, thinking I played it wrong I shuffled everything properly and tried again another day. Now the opposite problem presented itself. We were all constantly getting cards that didn't work with where we wanted our playthrough to go. So we had very few chains occurring. We were constantly trying to flush the cards we had to hope for new ones. The cards in the open market barely refresh anyway, so that made for a really dull playthrough. It figures, really, with cards so different form one another, in type, icons, and effects, it's no surprise this happens. The design simply doesn't manage probability and adds replayability through adding more cards in the mix. The deck makes the game unplayable for me.

Last thing I want to mention is the distinct absence of interactions in the game. Pretty much the only interaction is racing for card drafting in the open market or racing to complete missions before others.

I'm clearly missing whatever others are seeing in this game, but more power to whomever gets my used, like new copy.

The game can't seem to figure out what it wants players to do. It has a variety of opposing motivations, which isn't in and of itself bad except it doesn't seem interested in rewarding you properly. The game makes releasing animals an important late game activity, but the punishments far outweigh the benefits, which begs the question, what's the point? This carries through most of the activities of the game; what's the point? Why build kiosks if you're going to empty your enclosures? Why build multiple sponsors when only one or two will ever be useful? Is it possible the cards are *too* diverse?

All in all, I don't know who this game is for. Certainly not intense eurogamers, there's interaction and far too little control. Not engine builders, you're lucky to find two or three cards to work together. Certainly not families or people trying to break into the hobby.

I do like the action selection, but it's not original by any means, and the level two actions again don't feel worthwhile nor are the various limitations on action levels intuitive or easy to see or remember leading to numerous errors.

All in all this is an absolute disaster, too much going on, nothing gels or harmonizes. The game needed playtesting, needed editing, needed to be crafted into an experience. Sadly disappointing for such a well regarded game.

The bright and colourful artwork of some spectacular animals can't save this mess: the actual gameplay is disappointing on many levels, not only in the way in which it perpetuates current unsatisfying trends in game design, but also in some key flaws that it possesses even when judged by the standards of the current zeitgeist.

As is the current style, there are a multitude of actions and interlocking systems to explain, all with their own myriad details and little foibles. Much of these add very little to the actual decision space and, like with many recent releases, the result feels unfocused and sprawling, a mess of different systems without a clear, compelling core around which development could have focused on removing all of the surrounding noise. Like many recent games, too much happens on the individual boards in front of each player and the interaction is mostly made of a few races and some ill-fitting take-that effects on some of the cards. There is precious little compelling interaction with the other players.

The game design is reliant on the deck of cards, but here vital lessons have not been learned from Race for the Galaxy. Every card is as specific and as limited as Race's most situational card, Alien Tech Institute, except that here it's all of the cards, all of the time. I suspect that Ark Nova's deck needed to only have 4 continents and 4 types of animals. It definitely needed more generally applicable cards, and more cards with cross-over potential.

We probably shouldn't have individual card tableaux, individual player boards with jigsaw puzzle placement on a hex grid, the action-rotation-and-upgrading borrowed from Civilization: A New Dawn, a little worker placement board, a set of communal shared objectives, hidden objectives in player hands, AND a bunch of tracks to advance along, all competing for our attention in a single game. The one or two compelling pieces of this needed to identified, and then everything else ruthlessly removed. With all of that still present and combined with a badly-thought-out huge deck of cards, there's precious little here worth the considerable time investment.

I have played this game now 9 times (4 times solo) and I’ve come to a conclusion. TL;DR: I consider this a less interactive, strategic and more random version of TFM. To me personally also with a less interesting theme.

I don't like games where card control is something you have to unlock (like in WS) vs TFM (drafting) or ED (unlocked out of the box).
It can kill your chances already in the first round and this can also keep on going for multiple rounds. There's almost no mitigation otherwise. And I don't even mind that so much, like in WS, but then It's just waaayy too long for what It is. It doesn't add depth over time. It's just long.

I don't like having your own private zoo board vs a shared one (I.e. TFM) which adds interactivity, area-control or another level of planning and tension for top spots.

I don't like the (lack of) synergy between cards. It's not much of engine building, more about one-time (often wasted) powers, essentially to just prepare a cage for an animal. Any bonus can just come to players without any skill involved. The sponsor cards don't add much as a game strategy either. There's also something about the diversity of the cards that really make that "bad luck of the draw" sensation stronger. I guess that's because of the lack of engine building between cards to build something you can utilize better during the game, like TFM manages to do.
The tile laying doesn't offer much interesting decision-making either. It's really boring vs a shared interactive board like in TFM where timing, area-control and a race sensation creates that urgency and turn-angst.

The action selection mechanism is sort of fun though. It helps limit options, but at the same time creates more restrictions. I liked this mechanism in "Civ: new dawn" more to be honest. It adds to that "on rails" feeling I experience a lot while playing this game. I want to do this but the game state is telling me to do that. After finally trying it… I can say a few things about it.

1. It’s better than TM by far. The art is better, the theme is better, the game play is better, almost everything is better.

2. What’s NOT different than TM, is the amount of cards and the luck factor. You can’t have a “strategy” in this game period. It’s excessively tactical, but presents itself as a deep strategy game. Just like terraforming Mars does.

3. It could have had half the amount of cards. Way to much swing in that deck. LUCK should not play a major role in a 2+ hour game.

4. The public goals is a messy mechanism. You have both open goals, and then goals that can be played by players. Blehhh. Just cut one of those out of the game. Toooo much stuff!

5. The coffee break is a silly way to maintain updated. It required players to keep track of things they shouldn’t have to think about. This could have been handled by a deck timer or something easier.

6. The game is wayyy too long for such a lucky game. With some of the modifications I just mentioned it may play faster, but also I think the score track could be reduced to speed it even more. Because…

7. The “engine building” element is NOT strong in this. You get a few actions that get better, more icons in the tableau, etc. but you never really feel like you’re progressing. (And no I didn’t play poorly, I was a few points from winning.

8.There are about 5 other things that could have been cut from the game, or at least simplified. This is another one of those games that should have been developed more and trimmed down. Instead it was bloated up.

All in all I didn’t hate my play of it. I would play again if coaxed by a group and I was in the right mood. But I would probably need to be strongly coerced by friends who own it and want to play. I certainly don’t need a copy in my collection though as I would never reach for it over so many other games.

Ark Nova applies that logical conclusion to the multiplayer solitaire, no-interaction school of games.

In short this is "is it my turn yet?" the game. The core game mechanic is taking one of five actions, each action becomes more powerful the less you use it, so players need to manage when they play specific actions. These actions help you build up a zoo gaining points on a conservation track, and on an appeal track. Both tracks increase towards each other's starting position going in opposite directions. The object of the game is to score the greatest difference in points after the intersection/cross of both tracks.

The mechanics work well giving you options and control, yet still requiring the puzzle of tradeoff decisions. However there is little interaction, so the game is the quintessential multiplayer solitaire. For the amount of play time, the opportunity cost is too much for me, I'd rather play terraform mars or wingspan in half the time, then another game.


Pros:
------------
1. The action core game mechanic is fun. The actions getting stronger when unused is an incredibly fun mechanic. It gives players a tradeoff decision on their turn, do you perform the action now, or wait for extra bonuses? It also allows players to plan ahead, as things are predictable, and rewards good planning.

2. The ramp up time is quick. Some games you are limited in actions and understand how to build up the engine, but since the path is clear and determinate it feels very long till the gameplay starts to get fun. This game balances the control and options, making the ramp up feel quick.

3. The break mechanic is very well done (explanation of mechanic in feels good). It gives players the freedom

4. Getting bonuses is well done for pacing and gives player mini objectives to work towards. The game offers various bonuses from the conservation track, reputation track, association unlocks, and cards.

Cons:
--------------
1. This is the definition of multiplayer solitaire, there is no interaction at all. You never need to see what your opponents are doing aside from getting money/appeal when the place a unit, or seeing if they might take the card in the display or if they are competing against you for another objective. Your zoo is separate from everyone else's so you aren't incentivized to look at anything but your own (in terraform mars at least you are building the same world).

2. Feels like there are too many game mechanics that are good for the game, but complicate learning the game (e.g. players need to discard one secret objective after one player hits 10 conservation, or players need to play 1 extra associate, if they have already performed an identical associate actions).

3. Scoring. The tracks make it complicated, as once you cross tracks, you can no longer perform any actions. Players are incentivized to get as close to NOT crossing tracks, and then playing one more turn to cross tracks. Due to the limited options based on the cards you have, this can make the ending feel luck based. It's no longer who can score the most points, but who can get the tracks the closest without crossing, and then cross. This added layer complexity, though interesting, does not add to the game thematically or mechanically.

Feels Good:
--------------
1. The break mechanic. Asking people "are we going on break soon", or "I don't care I'm taking my break" or even begging people to not go on break. This is fun to say, and do.

*break mechanic explained*
There is a break track that triggers the "end" of the round, forcing players to reduce their hand and generate income. The break is triggered when the break track is completely incremented, it that gets incremented based on 2 actions (the number of spaces incremented can depend on what the triggering player chooses).

2. Planning out your plan and executing. There is enough predictability where you can plan and execute. There's also enough control where you can pivot when things go bad.

3. Even though there are many mechanics all of them work well together, and give you options.

Feels Bad
------------------
1. Discarding your cards when a break hits. (Similar to rolling 7 in catan).

2. Waiting for your turn. Because there's almost nothing other players can do to you, waiting for your turn is pointless, you don't care about what they do, as the worst they can do is take a card you want from the display, but there was little you could do to prevent or ramp up early to get that anyways. (Late game you can use the "cards action" early, or you can use the "animals 2 action" and play the card from the display, though at that point its an easy decision to perform the action earlier).

1. The whole game loop has a big tightness, but it is an artificial, feelbad tightness caused by how action selection mechanism works. Compare it to Age of Innovation or Seti, where tightness comes from resource management and is fun.
2. Feelbad is reinforced by big downtime - because of how action management works and how areas of interaction look, sometimes you are forced to reevaluate a complicated plan on the fly, taking time while others just sit and wait having little to do. There is no grace in it, just annoyance.
3. Iconography is often less than expressive, you often will end up checking the manual to understand what's going on.
4. Card-based play is disappointing. Playing animals requires multi-turn setup to optimize it while not giving a real satisfaction. It is mostly tactical with minor strategic aspect. Again it feels bad.
5. Cards are strikingly imbalanced. Some endgame objectives require huge effort. Other (like kiosks and pavillons based one) seem trivial. Same with sponsors and animals.
6. You aren't able to do much when stuck with hands that don't fit your strategy. In Terraforming Mars you can at least sell them without any prerequisites. Losing a hand full of cards on the break - another feelbad.

Guys, I don't need to be an established game designer to know that if I end up playing 5 hours and in the end my effort is evaluated in negative numbers, then it doesn't give a lot of fun, does it? Apparently there are some fixes done in which you add 100 points in the end but to be honest it means that instead of ending with negative points you end with points lower than these you were graciously given. Mind boggling.

All in all, now I see Ark Nova has a lot of problems and sins modern euros share. I don't see it as improvement over Terraforming Mars. While on TM some mechanics feel simplistic here they are overcomplicated, causing bad experience in general. That's all.

I really want to like Ark Nova. It’s very well-designed and blends a lot of game mechanics I enjoy, but for some reason the end result just doesn’t do anything for me. I even bought it again after selling it, feeling like I had to have missed something, but all of the hype and the love most people have for it never clicked with me.


Theme - 1.75/2

+ Building a zoo is a great theme that has mass appeal and the game has a nice, clean look to it, if a bit on the boring side.

+ Placing enclosures, filling them with animals, partnering with continents and universities, finding sponsors, etc., is all very thematic and has a clear impact on the game.

- Unfortunately, the zoo you build and the animals you choose don’t matter very much at the end of the game, since it comes down to a simple race for points. It’s missing the “I built something unique” feeling of Wingspan or Terraforming Mars, where you watch your engine come alive in the late game.


Rules Complexity - 1/2

- I found learning Ark Nova difficult and teaching it to others even harder. There are so many moving parts in this game and trying to distill it all into something that makes sense to first-timers is a tall task.

- Likewise, being the administrator of the game can be overwhelming as so many cards and bonuses can trigger between player turns and at the break.

Turn Simplicity - 0.75/2

+ Players use a series of rising and falling actions on their turn, with actions that aren’t used this turn increasing in power for the next. It adds an element of tension as players think about how long they can wait to do something.

- Even with just 5 possible actions, it’s easy for players to go down a rabbit hole trying to optimize what they do. After triggering a bunch of bonuses and other actions, players may realize a different sequence would have been better and want to unwind things.

Fun Factor - 1.5/2

+ Building out your zoo by placing tiles, especially early in the game, is a lot of fun. Adding a few animals to enclosures and reaping the benefits of more money and/or the ability to claim a conservation project creates a satisfying loop you want to repeat again and again.

+ After the first few turns, you’ll almost always trigger some sort of bonus and look forward to the next one.

- The zoo building is sadly pushed aside later in the game as it turns into a cutthroat race for points. Players will scramble to add any animals they can, especially those they may have held onto for the last turn.

Challenge and Replayability - 2/2

+ A huge deck of cards makes it infinitely replayable, especially with the marine expansion that also adds asymmetric cards for action selection.

+ The gameplay is incredibly tactical and the puzzle of figuring out which cards you can use, when you can punish your opponent with a break, and how to push everything across the finish line at just the right time is addictive.

+ There’s a high skill ceiling that will appeal to serious gamers.

A precision time-piece of finely tuned interlocking mechanisms, there is much more to Ark Nova than building enclosures, filling them with wildlife and funding projects.

Keeping an eye on who might snap that card you need, fund that award, or trigger the break bringing the turn to an end makes for a tense experience that belies the charming artwork and cute components.

The variety of park maps, ways to score, and huge range of cards keeps the game fresh, with new strategies and combos revealing themselves, even after 20+ plays.

While it can be hard to come back from an early bad turn, and is a bit low on player interaction for my taste, the game is such an addictive puzzle that I'll rarely turn it down.

Ark Nova – Imagine Terraforming Mars, but instead of turning a planet green, you’re filling your zoo with adorable animals and saving the world one conservation project at a time. Ark Nova is a brilliantly complex engine-builder where every card opens a new door — from building enclosures and breeding programs to sponsoring international wildlife efforts. The sheer variety of cards means no two zoos (or strategies) are ever the same: maybe you’ll focus on reptiles, maybe on primates, or maybe you’ll just try to get the wombat enclosure next to the lions for pure chaos. The action-selection system is genius — simple to grasp but endlessly deep — and the theme ties everything together so naturally that even your most cutthroat economic move feels oddly wholesome. It’s brainy, beautiful, and deeply satisfying — the rare heavy Euro that makes you feel good about your spreadsheet-level planning.
